statement.text: Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) is a chronic complication of deep venous thrombosis occurring in 20-50% of patients, characterized by persistent symptoms and signs of venous hypertension (pain, swelling, skin changes, ulceration) due to valve destruction, persistent obstruction, or both. Villalta score ≥5 diagnoses PTS; ≥15 or ulcer indicates severe PTS.
statement.formal: PTS: Villalta_Score ≥5 = Diagnosis; ≥15 or Ulcer = Severe; Develops in 20-50% of proximal DVT

explanation.intuition: When a blood clot forms in a deep vein and then dissolves, it often damages the one-way valves in that vein and may leave scarring that narrows the vein. This is like a flood that damages both the drainage pipes and the check valves - even after the floodwaters recede, the plumbing never works quite right again.
explanation.key_insight: PTS is not just 'swelling after DVT' - it's a specific syndrome diagnosed by the Villalta score that includes both symptoms (pain, heaviness, cramping) and signs (edema, skin changes). Iliofemoral DVT has the highest PTS risk because it involves the largest veins with the most critical valves.
explanation.technical_details: PTS pathophysiology involves two components: reflux from valve destruction and obstruction from incomplete thrombus recanalization. The DVT triggers an inflammatory response that damages valve leaflets, while organized thrombus may leave residual stenosis. Either mechanism leads to ambulatory venous hypertension - venous pressure fails to drop with walking. The Villalta scale quantifies 5 symptoms (pain, cramps, heaviness, pruritus, paresthesia) and 6 signs (edema, skin induration, hyperpigmentation, venous ectasia, redness, pain with calf compression), each scored 0-3.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: All leg swelling after DVT is PTS. Reality: Wait 3-6 months for acute changes to resolve before diagnosing PTS.
Misconception: Compression stockings prevent PTS. Reality: The SOX trial showed compression stockings do NOT prevent PTS, though they help manage symptoms.
Misconception: PTS is untreatable. Reality: Iliac stenting for obstruction is highly effective; valve surgery has limited role.

epidemiology.timing: Usually develops within 2 years of DVT; assess at 3-6 months

pathophysiology.consequence: Ambulatory venous hypertension - pressure fails to drop with walking

villalta_scale.description: Validated scoring system for PTS diagnosis and severity

signs.items: Edema, skin induration, hyperpigmentation, venous ectasia, redness, pain on calf compression

presentation: Leg pain (aching, heaviness, tiredness) worse with standing
diagnosis: Villalta score ≥5 (at least 3-6 months after DVT)
Duplex ultrasound for reflux and obstruction assessment

iliac_stenting.indication: Iliofemoral obstruction with Villalta ≥10 or ulcer

prevention.anticoagulation: Adequate intensity and duration is most important
prevention.compression_stockings: SOX trial showed NO prevention benefit
prevention.thrombolysis: May reduce PTS in iliofemoral DVT (CaVenT, ATTRACT trials)

definition.@value: A chronic complication of deep venous thrombosis characterized by persistent symptoms and signs of venous hypertension due to valve destruction, persistent obstruction, or both, diagnosed by Villalta score ≥5.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy
Lancet
sources.article: SOX Trial: Compression Stockings for PTS Prevention

learning_objectives: Understand pathophysiology of PTS (valve damage + obstruction)
Apply Villalta scale for diagnosis and severity grading
Identify risk factors for PTS development
clinical_pearls: PTS develops in 20-50% of proximal DVT patients; iliofemoral DVT = HIGHEST risk
Villalta score ≥5 = PTS diagnosis; ≥15 or ulcer = severe PTS
SOX trial: compression stockings do NOT prevent PTS (use for symptom management only)
Assess at least 3 months after DVT to diagnose PTS (allow acute changes to resolve)
Iliac stenting is highly effective for obstructive component
